the redirection there is done by the shell, which only has user permissions.  pipe to tee instead, for example:   echo "foo" | tee /some/file

do you understand what the > does?

ok, try this in your shell:  echo "foo"    then try this:   echo "foo" > ~/bar  .  You'll see that all that the '>' does is _redirect_ the output of the previous command to the file called ~/bar .  The shell is what actually does this redirection
